{{Short description|2018 referendum in Macedonia}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox referendum | name = Macedonian referendum, 2018 | country = Republic of Macedonia | title = Are you in favour of European Union and NATO membership by accepting the agreement between the Republic of Macedonia and the Republic of Greece? | yes = 609427 | no = 37687 | total = 666344 | electorate = 1806336 | map = Referendum Mazedonien 2018 Ja-Stimmen.svg | mapdivision = | notes = }} {{Politics of Macedonia}}
A referendum was held in the [[Republic of Macedonia]] on 30 September 2018, with voters asked whether they support [[European Union|EU]] and [[NATO]] membership by accepting [[Macedonia naming dispute#Prespa agreement|the agreement]] struck between the Republic of Macedonia and [[Greece]] in June 2018.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/macedonia-sets-sept--30-as-date-for-referendum-on-name-deal-with-greece-10575168 |title=Macedonia sets Sept. 30 for referendum on name deal with Greece |website=www.channelnewsasia.com |publisher=Channel NewsAsia |language=en-US |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/macedonia-sets-name-referendum-for-september-07-30-2018 |title=Macedonia Sets ‘Name’ Referendum for September |website=www.balkaninsight.com |publisher=Balkan Insight |language=en |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref> It is related to [[Macedonia naming dispute|the 27-year long dispute]] between Republic of Macedonia and Greece over the former's name, an issue which has prevented the accession of Macedonia to the European Union and NATO.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/macedonia-greece-sing-historic-name-deal-06-17-2018 |title=Macedonia, Greece Sign 'Historic' Name Deal |website=www.balkaninsight.com |publisher=Balkan Insight |language=en |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref> The government had carried out a social media campaign about the issue of the referendum.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/macedonia-govt-kicks-off-name-referendum-campaign-07-02-2018 |title=Macedonia Govt Starts 'Name' Referendum Campaign |website=www.balkaninsight.com |publisher=Balkan Insight |language=en |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref> The proposal ultimately failed on a constitutional ground because the turnout of eligible voters was not over 50 percent, according to the election commission.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-macedonia-referendum-turnout/macedonia-name-referendum-fails-to-reach-turnout-threshold-election-commission-idUSKCN1MA0X2 |title=Macedonia name referendum fails to reach turnout threshold: election commission |website=reuters.com |publisher=Reuters |language=en-UK |access-date=1 October 2018}}</ref> This led the opposition to claim victory, while the government did as well by arguing that the result being non-binding meant the turnout requirement was pointless in the first place. Being non-binding, as well as including constitutional changes, its result will still need to be approved by two-thirds of parliament.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.eurasiareview.com/23092018-no-disputing-macedonia-is-at-a-watershed-moment-analysis/ |title=No Disputing Macedonia Is At A Watershed Moment – Analysis |date=23 September 2018 |website=www.eurasiareview.com |publisher=Eurasia Review |language=en-US |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref> [[Prime Minister of Macedonia|Macedonian Prime Minister]] [[Zoran Zaev]] has vowed to push forward with the changes in parliament.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sekularac |first1=Ivana |title=Macedonia leader vows to press on with name change despite... |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-macedonia-referendum/macedonia-leader-vows-to-press-on-with-name-change-despite-referendum-failure-idUSKCN1M90U1?il=0 |accessdate=1 October 2018 |work=Reuters}}</ref>
==Background== Following [[SR Macedonia|Macedonia]]'s independence from [[SFR Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] in 1991, successive [[Greece|Greek]] governments have claimed that the country's name implied territorial claims on [[Greek Macedonia]] and have objected to the use of "Macedonia" by the new state. It was admitted to the [[United Nations]] in 1993 as "the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia" (FYROM),<ref name="UNSC res. 817">{{cite web |url=http://unscr.com/en/resolutions/doc/817|title=United Nations Security Council Resolution 817 |date=7 April 1993 |publisher=[[United Nations Security Council]] |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref> while most countries have [[List of countries' positions in the Macedonia naming dispute#Countries/entities using "Republic of Macedonia" for bilateral purposes|recognised the Republic of Macedonia under its constitutional name]].
Repeated attempts at negotiation for a composite name failed for 27 years. However, in 2018, high-level contacts between the governments of the two countries intensified, with the Macedonian Deputy Prime Minister [[Bujar Osmani]] visiting [[Athens]] for the name talks on 9 January,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/macedonia-greece-name-dispute-osmani-talks/28965566.html|title=Macedonian Deputy PM In Athens For Talks On Name Dispute |website=www.rferl.org |publisher=RFERL |accessdate=24 January 2018}}</ref> and [[Prime Minister of Macedonia|Macedonian Prime Minister]] [[Zoran Zaev]] meeting with his [[Prime Minister of Greece|Greek]] counterpart [[Alexis Tsipras]] on the sidelines of the [[World Economic Forum]] at [[Davos]], [[Switzerland]] on 24 January.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://neoskosmos.com/news/en/Greece-and-FYROM-PMs-to-meet-over-Macedonia-name-dispute|title=Greece and FYROM PMs to meet over ‘Macedonia’ name dispute|website=www.neoskosmos.com|publisher=Neos Kosmos|accessdate=24 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/pms-to-meet-after-macedonia-name-dispute-rally-in-greece|title=PMs to meet after 'Macedonia' name dispute rally in Greece |website=www.sbs.com |publisher=SBS |accessdate=24 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://nezavisen.mk/en/news/2018/01/18809/ |title=Tsipras and Zaev unblock Euro-integration process|accessdate=24 January 2018}}</ref> In the Davos meeting, the first of its kind in seven years, there appeared to be some resolution between the two leaders to end the naming dispute and to improve the [[Greece-Macedonia relations|relations between the two countries]]. Zaev subsequently agreed to take initiatives that would soothe Greek concerns over [[antiquisation]] policies, while Tsipras agreed to consent to [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]'s bid to join regional initiatives or agreements.
On 12 June 2018, Tsipras announced that he had reached an agreement with Zaev "which covers all the preconditions set by the Greek side".<ref name="2018Deal">{{cite web |title=‘We have a deal,’ Greek PM says over FYROM name row |url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/229552/article/ekathimerini/news/we-have-a-deal-greek-pm-says-over-fyrom-name-row |website=www.ekathimerini.com |publisher=Η Καθημερινή |accessdate=12 June 2018 |language=en |date=12 June 2018}}</ref> The proposal would result in the Republic of Macedonia being renamed the Republic of North Macedonia ({{Lang-mk|Република Северна Македонија|translit=Republika Severna Makedonija}}), with the new name being used for all purposes.<ref name="2018DealName">{{cite web |title=Greece ends 27-year Macedonia name row |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-44401643 |website=www.bbc.com |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=12 June 2018 |date=12 June 2018}}</ref> Zaev announced that the deal includes recognition of the [[Macedonian language]] in the [[United Nations]] and that the [[citizenship]] of the country will be called, Macedonian/citizen of the Republic of North Macedonia. Also, there would be an explicit clarification that the citizens of the country are not related to the [[ancient Macedonians]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Republic of North Macedonia with Macedonian language and identity, says Greek media |url=http://meta.mk/en/republic-of-north-macedonia-with-macedonian-language-and-identity-says-greek-media/ |website=www.eta.mk|publisher=Meta |accessdate=12 June 2018 |date=12 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Κλείδωσε το «Βόρεια Μακεδονία» - Το διάγγελμα Τσίπρα για τη συμφωνία|url=http://www.kathimerini.gr/969055/article/epikairothta/politikh/kleidwse-to-voreia-makedonia---to-diaggelma-tsipra-gia-th-symfwnia |trans-title=Agreed on «North Macedonia» {{endash}} Tsipras' speech to the nation about the deal |language=greek|website=kathimerini.gr |publisher=Kathimerini |accessdate=12 June 2018 |date=12 June 2018}}</ref> "The agreement once and for always confirms and strengthens the [[Macedonians (ethnic group)|Macedonian]] ethnic and [[cultural identity]], the Macedonian language, the Macedonian [[nationality]]. It guarantees the security of the country and provides a secure future for the citizens of the Republic of Macedonia", Zaev said.<ref name="Zaev12062018">{{cite web |title=Zaev:We made a deal - Republic of North Macedonia, with Macedonian language and Macedonian identity |url=https://kajgana.com/zaev-postignavme-dogovor-republika-severna-makedonija-so-makedonski-jazik-i-makedonski-identitet |website=www.kajgana.com|publisher=Кајгана |accessdate=12 June 2018 |language=mk |date=12 June 2018}}</ref> These changes were to be put to a referendum for citizens of the Republic of Macedonia in September 2018. Additionally, the agreement stipulates the removal of the [[Vergina Sun]] from public use in the Republic of Macedonia and the formation of a committee for the review of school textbooks and maps in both countries for the removal of irredentist content and to align them with [[UNESCO]] and [[Council of Europe]]'s standards.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.crashonline.gr/epikairotita/1164670/chanetai-kai-o-ilios-tis-verginas-ti-orizei-i-symfonia-gia-to-sima/|title=Χάνεται και «ο Ηλιος της Βεργίνας»: Τι ορίζει η συμφωνία για το σήμα|trans-title=The «Sun of Vergina» is also being lost: what the agreement states|website=www.crashonline.gr|lang=el|publisher=Crash Online |date=14 June 2018|accessdate=22 June 2018}}</ref> The agreement was signed at [[Lake Prespa]], a body of water which is divided among Macedonia, Greece and [[Albania]].
[[Assembly of the Republic of Macedonia|Parliament]] paved the way for the referendum by ratifying the agreement for a second time in early July.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.rappler.com/world/regions/europe/206621-macedonia-parliament-ratify-greece-deal-referendum |title=Macedonia MPs ratify Greece deal, paving way for referendum |website=www.rappler.com |publisher=Rappler |language=en |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref> After a month long delay by the opposition party [[VMRO-DPMNE]] to slow down the referendum preparation by not appointing members to the State Election Commission, the parliament finally agreed as of the end of July on a new composition.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/macedonia-opposition-puts-name-referendum-at-risk-07-10-2018 |title=Macedonia Opposition Puts ‘Name’ Referendum at Risk |website=www.balkaninsight.com |publisher=Balkan Insight |language=en |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/macedonia-unlocks-referendum-preparations-07-26-2018 |title=Macedonia Starts Work on Referendum Preparations |website=www.balkaninsight.com |publisher=Balkan Insight |language=en |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref>
==Question== The text of the question put to voters was:
{{Quote|Are you in favour of European Union and NATO membership by accepting the agreement between the Republic of Macedonia and the Republic of Greece?<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://euobserver.com/tickers/142494 |title=Macedonia sets question for name referendum |language=en |access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref>}}
==Support== [[File:Pro Macedonian referendum billboard 2018.jpg|thumb|right|Pro-Macedonian referendum billboard in [[Debar]]. Translated it reads: The EU helps Macedonia with 260,000 euros a day. Together for a European Macedonia.]] [[Prime Minister of Macedonia|Macedonian Prime Minister]] [[Zoran Zaev]] and the government coalition started an online campaign for a “Yes” vote in the referendum. Many high-ranked officials and [[European Union|EU]] leaders expressed their support for the "Yes" option as it would bring [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] closer to EU and [[NATO]]. Among those who visited the country in support of the referendum are [[Angela Merkel]] and [[Sebastian Kurz]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/germany-s-merkel-in-macedonia-for-talks-ahead-of-key-referendum/29478758.html|title=Merkel Urges Macedonians To Vote For Name Change, Possibility For EU, NATO Membership|website=www.rferl.org|publisher=RFERL|accessdate=24 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://meta.mk/en/kurz-will-visit-macedonia-to-support-the-referendum-on-7th-of-september/|title=Kurz will visit Macedonia to support the referendum on 7th of September|website=www.meta.mk|publisher=Meta|accessdate=24 September 2018}}</ref> [[Chancellor]]s of [[Germany]] and [[Austria]] respectively, as well as [[Jim Mattis]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-macedonia-usa/mattis-warns-of-russian-meddling-in-macedonia-vote-idUSKCN1LX0ER|title=U.S. Defense Secretary warns of Russian meddling in Macedonia referendum|website=www.reuters.com|publisher=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=24 September 2018}}</ref> the [[United States Secretary of Defence|US Defense Secretary]], and [[Jens Stoltenberg]], the [[Secretary General of NATO]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://europeanwesternbalkans.com/2018/09/04/stoltenberg-kurz-macedonia-merkel/|title=Stoltenberg and Kurz in Macedonia before Merkel|website=www.europeanwesternbalkans.com|publisher=European Western Balkans|accessdate=24 September 2018}}</ref> who encouraged the people of Macedonia to vote in favor of the new name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/west-in-diplomatic-push-in-macedonia-ahead-of-referendum-09-04-2018|title=West in Diplomatic Push to Boost Macedonia Referendum|website=www.balkaninsight.com|publisher=Balkan Insight|accessdate=24 September 2018}}</ref> The [[President of Albania|Albanian President]] [[Ilir Meta]], [[Prime Minister of Albania|Prime Minister]] [[Edi Rama]] and [[Minister for Europe and Foreign Affairs (Albania)|Foreign Minister]] [[Ditmir Bushati]] also urged [[Albanians in the Republic of Macedonia|Albanians in Macedonia]] to support the deal and vote “Yes” in the referendum.<ref name="balkaninsightmeta">{{cite web|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/albanian-president-calls-albanian-to-vote-for-name-deal-08-30-2018|title=Meta Urges Macedonia Albanians to Vote 'Yes' to Deal|website=www.balkaninsight.com|publisher=Balkan Insight|accessdate=1 October 2018}}</ref><ref name="IljaziBushati">{{cite web|last=Iljazi|first=Bashkim|title=Bushati: Qytetarët e Maqedonisë ta mbështesin procesin e anëtarësimit të vendit në NATO dhe BE|url=https://telegrafi.com/bushati-qytetaret-e-maqedonise-ta-mbeshtesin-procesin-e-anetaresimit-te-vendit-ne-nato-dhe-video/|website=www.telegrafi.com |publisher=Telegrafi|accessdate=1 October 2018}}</ref><ref name="IljaziRama">{{cite web|last=Iljazi|first=Bashkim|title=Edi Rama mesazh shqiptarëve të Maqedonisë: Sot votohet për të ardhmen e fëmijëve|url=https://telegrafi.com/edi-rama-mesazh-shqiptareve-te-maqedonise-sot-votohet-per-te-ardhmen-e-femijeve/|website=www.telegrafi.com |publisher=Telegrafi|accessdate=1 October 2018}}</ref> In Macedonia, [[Albanians|Albanian]] political parties and their leaders [[Ali Ahmeti]] ([[Democratic Union for Integration|DUI]]), [[Menduh Thaçi]] ([[Democratic Party of Albanians|DPA]]), Bilall Kasami ([[Besa Movement]]) and Ziadin Sela ([[Alliance for Albanians]]) supported the “Yes” vote.<ref name="shqiptarja">{{cite web|url=http://shqiptarja.com/lajm/referendumi-n-maqedoni-gorenca-pjesmarrja-e-ult-shqiptart-s-kan-dal-pr-t-votuar-masivisht|title=Referendumi për emrin, liderët e partive shqiptare në Maqedoni votojnë 'pro'|website=www.shqiptarja.com|publisher=Shqiptarja|accessdate=1 October 2018}}</ref>
==Opposition== [[File:Banners Bojkotiram movement.jpg|thumb|right|Banners and posters of the boycott movement ''Bojkotiram'' opposite to the [[Assembly of the Republic of Macedonia]] in [[Skopje]], three days after the referendum]] [[File:Macedonian referendum boycott poster 2018.jpg|thumb|right|Macedonian referendum boycott poster in [[Struga]]. Translated it reads: Who gave you the rights to change our name and identity? Our name is Macedonia #I will boycott]] The main opposition party [[VMRO-DPMNE]] threatened to boycott the referendum and considered the deal with [[Greece]] to be an act of treason. In early September, the party's president [[Hristijan Mickoski]] came out with a statement encouraging citizens to vote as they feel it is right for their country's future, and that the party would respect different opinions.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://nezavisen.mk/en/news/2018/09/90095/ |title=Mickoski: The majority of VMRO-DPMNE supporters would either abstain or vote ‘against’ |website=www.nezavisen.mk |publisher=Nezavisen |language=en-EN |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref> The party did not participate in the referendum campaign, while various high ranking party members voiced their support for the boycott or the “Yes” side. In early September, a cable from the [[United States Ambassador to Macedonia|US embassy in the Republic of Macedonia]] revealed by [[WikiLeaks]] showed that the 2008 VMRO-DPMNE government was willing to accept the name {{em|Republic of North Macedonia}}, for international and bilateral use only, provided it included the recognition of the [[Macedonian language]] and [[nationality]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://wikileaks.org/plusd/cables/08SKOPJE491_a.html |title=Macedonia/Greece: What the Macedonians Need to Resolve the Name Dispute |date=29 July 2008 |website=www.wikileaks.org |publisher=[[WikiLeaks]] |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/232251/article/ekathimerini/news/wikileaks-fyrom-would-have-accepted-north-macedonia-in-2008 |title=Wikileaks: FYROM would have accepted 'North Macedonia' in 2008 |website=www.ekathimerini.com |publisher=[[Kathimerini]] |language=en |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref> That proposal was rejected by Greece.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://euobserver.com/tickers/142722 |title=Wikileaks: FYROM would have accepted new name in 2008 |website=www.euobserver.com |publisher=EU Observer |language=en |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref> The information has been denied by media close to the party,<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://kurir.mk/makedonija/vesti/kodzijas-za-vikiliks-dokumentot-gruevski-ne-prifati-ni-severna-ni-erga-omnes/ |title=Груевски не прифати ни „Северна“ ни „ерга омнес“ |website=www.kurir.mk |publisher=Kurir |language=mk |trans-title=Gruevski did not accept neither "north" nor "erga omnes" |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://bukefal.club/2018/09/03/vikiliks-severna-makedonija-bilo-prifatlivo-ushte-vo-2008-ma-no-edna-vazhna-razlika/ |title=Викиликс: „Северна Македонија“ било прифатливо уште во 2008-ма, но со една важна разлика - Bukefal |date=3 September 2018 |website=www.bukefal.club |publisher=Bukefal |language=en-US |trans-title=WikiLeaks: "North Macedonia" was acceptable in 2008, but with one important difference |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref> which have stated that VMRO-DPMNE was only willing to accept changing the FYROM reference to North Macedonia, while keeping the constitutional name the same. On 23 September, [[President of Macedonia|Macedonia's President]] [[Gorge Ivanov]], who was elected as a candidate of the VMRO-DPMNE, decried the agreement and called on his compatriots to boycott the vote. Various other small [[Anti-Western sentiment|anti-Western]] organizations{{which|date=October 2018}} with pro-[[Serbia]]n and pro-[[Russia]]n orientations have also organized protests against the name change.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-macedonia-greece-name/more-than-1000-macedonians-protest-countrys-name-change-idUSKBN1JJ165 |title=More than 1,000 Macedonians protest country's name change |website=www.reuters.com |publisher=[[Reuters]] |language=en-US |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref>
Among the [[Macedonian diaspora]], the majority of [[Macedonian Australians|Macedonians living in Australia]] expressed that they would boycott the referendum vote.<ref name="DabbaghSBS">{{cite web|last=Dabbagh|first=Omar|title=Majority of Macedonian Australians boycotting name-change referendum|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/majority-of-macedonian-australians-boycotting-name-change-referendum|website=www.sbs.com.au|publisher=SBS|accessdate=4 October 2018}}</ref>
===Russian interference=== Various diplomats and analysts<ref name=Telegraph/>, including [[United States Secretary of Defence|U.S. Defense Secretary]] [[Jim Mattis]],<ref name="Polygraph"/> have accused [[Russia]] of engaging in a campaign to undermine the referendum. Russia is opposed to any additional countries joining [[NATO]] or the [[European Union]].<ref name=Time>{{cite news |last1=Perrigo |first1=Billy |title=How the Renaming of Country Became A Battleground Between Russia and the West |url=http://time.com/5415031/macedonia-rename/ |accessdate=4 October 2018 |work=Time |date=4 October 2018 |language=en}}</ref> Thousands of fake [[Twitter]] and [[Facebook]] accounts urged [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonians]] to boycott the vote.<ref name=Telegraph>{{cite news |last1=Squires |first1=Nick |title=Russia 'orchestrating covert campaign to wreck Macedonia name change vote' |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/09/27/russia-orchestrating-covert-campaign-wreck-macedonia-name-change/ |accessdate=4 October 2018 |work=The Telegraph |date=27 September 2018}}</ref> Some Facebook postings asked "are you going to let [[Albanians in the Republic of Macedonia|Albanians]] change your name?", attempting to exploit ethnic divisions in the country.<ref name="Tisdall">{{cite web|last=Tisdall|first=Simon|title=Result of Macedonia's referendum is another victory for Russia|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/oct/01/result-of-macedonia-referendum-is-another-victory-for-russia|website=www.theguardian.com |publisher=Guardian|accessdate=1 October 2018}}</ref> The "No" lobby banked on a boycott that could render the referendum result meaningless.<ref name="Polygraph">{{Cite web |url=https://www.polygraph.info/a/fact-check-macedonia-name-change-boycott/29486644.html |title=Updated: Largest Opposition Party in Macedonia is Not Boycotting Name Referendum |website=www.polygraph.info |publisher=Polygraph |language=en |access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref> Two Russian diplomats were expelled from [[Greece]] due to accusations of attempting to undermine relations with Macedonia,<ref name=Telegraph/> and a year earlier Russian citizens were arrested related to [[Montenegrin coup plot|a failed coup]] in [[Montenegro]] attempting to prevent that country from joining NATO.<ref name=Time/>
==Opinion polls== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center;font-size:95%;line-height:14px" ! Date(s) conducted ! data-sort-type="number" style="background:green; color:white; width:100px;"| Yes ! data-sort-type="number" style="background:#dc241f; color:white; width:100px;"| No ! data-sort-type="number" style="background:silver; width:100px;"| Undecided ! data-sort-type="number" style="width:100px;"| Will not vote ! data-sort-type="number" | Error margin ! data-sort-type="number" | Sample ! Conducted by ! Method |- | data-sort-value="2018-06-28" style="background:#D5D5D5"|''28 June – 15 July 2018'' |style="background: rgb(177, 255, 177);"|'''49%''' |22% |13% |16% |± 3.0% |1100 respondents aged 18 and over |[https://www.iri.org/sites/default/files/iri_macedonia_july_2018_poll_public_final.pdf IRI] | Face-to-face interviews |- | data-sort-value="2018-07-24" style="background:#D5D5D5"|''24 July – 1 August 2018'' |style="background: rgb(177, 255, 177);"|'''41.5%''' |35.1% |9.2% |12.4% |± 3.1% |1026 likely voters |[http://www.mcms.mk/images/docs/2018/referendum-2018-public-opinion-poll-in-macedonia.pdf MCIC] | Computer-assisted telephone interview |}
==Results== [[File:Referendum Mazedonien Beteiligung.svg|thumb|right|Turnout in the quota referendum by municipalities]] In fifteen municipalities of Macedonia predominantly inhabited by [[Albanians in the Republic of Macedonia|Albanians]], voter turnout was at 233,000 people and marginally less than in the local elections of 2017.<ref name="Trpkovski">{{cite web|last=Trpkovski|first=Goce|title=Albanian Vote Not Crucial in Macedonia Referendum Shortfall|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/albanian-vote-not-crucial-in-macedonia-referendum-shortfall-10-02-2018|website=www.Balkaninsight.com|publisher=Balkaninsight|accessdate=4 October 2018}}</ref> Albanians from Macedonia residing in [[Western Europe]] ignored voting in the referendum.<ref name="Bechev">{{cite web|last=Bechev|first=Dimitar|title=What next after the failed Macedonian referendum?|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/failed-macedonian-referendum-181001185416308.html|website=www.aljazeera.com|publisher=Aljazeera|accessdate=4 October 2018}}</ref>
{| class=wikitable style=text-align:right !Choice !Votes !% |- |align=left|For||609,427||94.18<!-- Yes + No should sum to 100%. See the infobox--> |- |align=left|Against||37,687||5.82 |- |align=left|Invalid/blank votes||19,221||– |- |align=left|'''Total'''||'''666,344'''||'''100''' |- |align=left|Registered voters/turnout||1,806,336|| 36.89 |- |align=left colspan=3|Source: [https://referendum.sec.mk/Referendum/Results?cs=en-US&r=r&rd=r1&eu=All&m=All SEC] |}
==Aftermath== ===International reactions=== [[Western world|Western]] leaders welcomed the result as positive, despite the low turnout. The [[European Commissioner for Enlargement and European Neighbourhood Policy|European Union's Commissioner for Neighbourhood and Enlargement Negotiations]], [[Johannes Hahn]], called the “Yes” vote "very significant" and urged [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]'s political leaders to "respect this decision and take it forward with utmost responsibility". [[NATO]] chief, [[Jens Stoltenberg]], in his post on [[Twitter]] described the referendum as a "historic opportunity", while reaffirming that "NATO’s door is open" for Macedonia. The [[United States]] also welcomed the outcome, with the [[United States Department of State|State Department]] urging Macedonian lawmakers "to rise above partisan politics and seize this historic opportunity" in implementing the [[Macedonia naming dispute#Prespa agreement|Prespa agreement]], which could enable Macedonia to become "a full participant in Western institutions".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/all/news/eu-and-nato-welcome-macedonias-referendum-result-despite-low-turnout/|title=EU and NATO hail Macedonia’s referendum result despite low turnout|website=EURACTIV.com with AFP and Reuters|accessdate=4 October 2018}}</ref> [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Greece)|Greece's Foreign Ministry]] welcomed the positive result, but described it as "contradictory" to the low vote turnout,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.gr/entry/elleniko-epoeryeio-exoterikon-antifatiko-to-apotelesma-toe-demopsefismatos-sten-pydm_gr_5bb11bcfe4b0343b3dc13c3c?ncid=other_topnaventr_coabgdcpxri&utm_campaign=topnav|title=Greek Ministry of Foreign Affairs: the outcome of the referendum in the Republic of Macedonia is contradictory (Original: Ελληνικό Υπουργείο Εξωτερικών: Αντιφατικό το αποτέλεσμα του δημοψηφίσματος στην πΓΔΜ)|website=Huffington Post|accessdate=4 October 2018}}</ref> and the [[Prime Minister of Greece|Greek Prime Minister]] [[Alexis Tsipras]] phoned his [[Prime Minister of Macedonia|Macedonian]] counterpart [[Zoran Zaev]] right after the referendum to congratulate him for the positive outcome.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amna.gr/en/article/297067/Tsipras-congratulates-Zaev-on-determination-to-implement-the-agreement|title=Tsipras congratulates Zaev on determination to implement the agreement|website=ANMA|date=1 October 2018|accessdate=4 October 2018}}</ref>
[[Russia]], a staunch opponent of Macedonia's Euro-Atlantic integration, on the other hand, hinted that it could veto the Prespa agreement between the Republic of Macedonia and Greece, by bringing it to the [[United Nations]] [[United Nations Security Council|Security Council]]. Macedonia dismissed [[Moscow]]'s threats by stating that bilateral agreements can not be dependent on the [[United Nations Security Council|Security Council]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/233223/article/ekathimerini/news/name-deal-in-the-balance-as-russia-hints-at-un-veto|title=Name deal in the balance as Russia hints at UN veto|website=Kathimerini|date=2 October 2018|accessdate=4 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/macedonia-dismisses-russian-threat-on-name-agreement-10-03-2018|title=Macedonia Dismisses Russian 'Threat' to Name Deal|website=BalkanInsight|date=4 October 2018|accessdate=4 October 2018}}</ref>
===Macedonia=== On 19 October 2018, [[Assembly of the Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia’s Parliament]] voted to start the process of renaming the country Republic of North Macedonia. A total of 80 deputies in the 120-seat parliament voted in favour of the renaming proposal—just reaching the two-thirds majority needed to enact constitutional changes, a quorum only needing to be met, and no more.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/oct/20/welcome-to-north-macedonia-parliament-votes-for-name-change|title=Welcome to North Macedonia: parliament votes for name change|website=The Guardian|date=20 October 2018}}</ref>

'''Memorialization''' generally refers to the process of preserving memories of people or events. It can be a form of address or petition, or a ceremony of remembrance or commemoration.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | title =Memorialization | encyclopedia =[[Merriam-Webster Dictionary]] | edition =Online | url =http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/memorialization }}</ref><ref>{{OED | Memorialisation }}</ref>
==Memorialization as a Human Right== Memorialization is a universal need for both those being memorialized and those who are grieving. Although historically it was limited to the elite and only practiced in the highest societal classes, it is now almost considered a fundamental [[human right]] for all people.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.memorialized.com/ |title=Memorialized |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2002 |website=Memorialized.com |publisher= |access-date=}}</ref>
==Memorialization and Transitional Justice== In the context of [[transitional justice]], memorialization is used to honor the victims of human rights abuses. Memorials can help governments reconcile tensions with victims by demonstrating respect and acknowledging the past. They can also help to establish a record of history, and to prevent the recurrence of abuse.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ictj.org/our-work/transitional-justice-issues/truth-and-memory |title=Truth and Memory |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=[[International Center for Transitional Justice]] (ICTJ) |publisher= |access-date=}}</ref>
Memorials can also be serious social and political forces in democracy-building efforts.<ref>{{Cite report |first1=Sebastian |last1=Brett |first2=Louis |last2=Bickford |first3=Liz |last3=Ševčenko |first4=Marcela |last4=Rios |date=2007 |title=Memorialization and Democracy: State Policy and Civic Action |url=http://ictj.org/publication/memorialization-and-democracy-state-policy-and-civic-action |publisher=International Center for Transitional Justice (ICTJ) |format=PDF |accessdate= |quote= }}</ref>
Memorials are also a form of [[Reparations (transitional justice)|reparations]], or compensation efforts that seek to address past [[human rights violations]].<ref>{{Cite book|title = Memorials in Times of Transition|last = Buckley-Zistel, S. / Schäfer, S. (eds.)|first = |publisher = Intersentia|year = 2014|isbn = 9781780682112|location = Antwerp|pages = }}</ref> They aim to provide compensation for losses endured by victims of abuse, and remedy prior wrongdoing. They also publicly recognize that victims are entitled to redress and respect. The United Nations Basic Principles on the Right to a Remedy and Reparation recognizes “commemorations and tributes to the victims” as a form of reparation.<ref>{{Cite report | author = General Assembly of the United Nations | author-link = United Nations | title = Basic Principles and Guidelines on the Right to a Remedy and Reparation for Victims of Gross Violations of International Human Rights Law and Serious Violations of International Humanitarian Law, Adopted and proclaimed by General Assembly resolution 60/147 of 16 December 2005 | url = http://www.ohchr.org/EN/ProfessionalInterest/Pages/RemedyAndReparation.aspx | publisher = Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights | date = 21 March 2006 | docket = | access-date = | quote = }}</ref>
There are numerous types of memorials used as [[transitional justice]] initiatives. These include architectural memorials, museums, and other commemorative events. For instance, in northern [[Uganda]], monuments, annual prayer ceremonies, and a mass grave were created in response to the war conducted by and against the [[Lord’s Resistance Army]] there.<ref>{{Cite report |last=Hopwood |first=Julian | date =February 2011 | title =We Can’t Be Sure Who Killed Us: Memory and Memorialization in Post-conflict Northern Uganda | url =http://ictj.org/publication/we-can%E2%80%99t-be-sure-who-killed-us-memory-and-memorialization-post-conflict-northern-uganda | publisher =International Center for Transitional Justice (ICTJ) | format =PDF }}</ref>
Another example is the [[Museum of Memory and Human Rights]] in [[Chile]], which was created to document abuses by the former [[military dictatorship]] there.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.museodelamemoria.cl/el-museo/sobre-el-museo/ |title=Sobre el Museo |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=20 April 2012 |website=Museo de la Memoria y los Derechos Humanos |language=Spanish |access-date=9 February 2015}}</ref>
==Challenges of Memorialization== Memorialization can arouse controversy and present certain risks. In unstable political situations, memorials may increase desire for revenge and catalyze further violence. They are highly politicized processes that represent the will of those in power. They are thus difficult to shape, and international relief workers, [[Peacekeeping|peacekeepers]], and [[NGOs]] risk being drawn into disputes about the creation or maintenance of memorial sites. Yet they also have the potential to redress historical grievances and enable societies to progress.<ref>{{Cite report | url = http://www.usip.org/publications/urge-remember-role-memorials-social-reconstruction-and-transitional-justice | title = The Urge to Remember: The Role of Memorials in Social Reconstruction and Transitional Justice | last1 = Barsalou | first1 = Judy | last2 = Baxter | first2=Victoria | date = 1 January 2007 | website = United States Institute of Peace | format = PDF | series = Stabilization and Reconstruction }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Truth-seeking]] * [[Transitional Justice]] * [[Transitional Justice Institute]] * [[Reparations (transitional justice)]] * [[Yom HaShoah#Commemoration|Yom HaShoah (Holocaust and Heroism Remembrance Day) Israel]] * [[National Day of Commemoration|National Day of Commemoration (Ireland)]] * [[Mourning of Muharram|Commemoration of Husayn ibn Ali]] * [[Khojaly Massacre|Khojaly Massacre Commemoration Day]] * [[Remembrances of the Mountain Meadows massacre|Commemorations of the Mountain Meadows massacre]] * [[Holocaust Memorial Days]] * [[Workers' Memorial Day|International Commemoration Day for Dead and Injured]] * [[Gettysburg Rostrum|Gettysburg Rostrum (Battlefield venue for historical commemorations)]] * [[Crime Victims' Rights Week]] Annual United States commemoration that promotes victims' rights and services. * [[Maaveerar Day]] or Heroes' Day. Commemoration observed by Tamil people to remember the deaths of militants. * [[Sacred Defence Week]] Iranian annual commemoration of the 1980-1988 Iran-Iraq war. * [[Bataan Memorial Death March]] Annual commemoration of the [[Bataan Death March]].
==Further reading== * Tobie S. Meyer-Fong. ''What Remains: Coming to Terms with Civil War in 19th Century China.'' (Stanford, CA: Stanford University Press, 2013). {{ISBN|9780804754255}}. A study of the [[Taiping rebellion]] in mid 19th century China: its victims, their experience of the war, and the memorialization of the war. * Report of the Special Rapporteur in the field of cultural rights, Farida Shaheed Memorialization processes http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/Issues/CulturalRights/A-HRC-25-49_en.pdf *Louis Bickford, “Memoryworks/memory works”, in Transitional Justice, Culture and Society: Beyond Outreach, Clara Ramírez-Barat, ed. (New York, Social Science Research Council, 2014): https://s3.amazonaws.com/ssrc-cdn1/crmuploads/new_publication_3/%7B222A3D3D-C177-E311-A360-001CC477EC84%7D.pdf
==External links== * [https://www.ictj.org/our-work/transitional-justice-issues/truth-and-memory International Center for Transitional Justice, Truth and Memory page]

The '''Ministry of Justice''' is a ministry of the [[government of Niue]].
Per the Niue Constitution Act of 1974, the Minister of Justice provided advice to the Governor-General regarding the selection of Judges of the High Court.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mbarral.webs.ull.es/NiueConstitutionAct1974.html|title=Niue - Legislation - Niue Constitution Act 1974|website=mbarral.webs.ull.es|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref> As of 2008, the ministry went by the name Ministry of Justice, Lands and Survey. Based on the government's website in 2018, the justice affairs appear to have merged with the Ministry of Social Services—as there is no separate section for the Ministry of Justice. As of 2018, records show Darren Tohovaka as the Acting Secretary of Justice.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gov.nu/wb/pages/ministries.php|title=Government of Niue - Ministries|website=www.gov.nu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref>
== List of ministers ==
* [[Enetama Lipitoa]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112083085156;view=1up;seq=80|title=Chiefs of State and Cabinet members of foreign governments / National Foreign Assessment Center. 1984:Oct.-Dec..|website=HathiTrust|language=en|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=osu.32435024019853;view=1up;seq=80|title=Chiefs of State and Cabinet members of foreign governments / National Foreign Assessment Center. 1985.|website=HathiTrust|language=en|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015073049366;view=1up;seq=68|title=Chiefs of State and Cabinet members of foreign governments / National Foreign Assessment Center. 1990.|website=HathiTrust|language=en|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref> (1985-1990) * [[Young Vivian]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015073049051;view=1up;seq=66|title=Chiefs of State and Cabinet members of foreign governments / National Foreign Assessment Center. 1991.|website=HathiTrust|language=en|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015073049200;view=1up;seq=69|title=Chiefs of State and Cabinet members of foreign governments / National Foreign Assessment Center. 1992.|website=HathiTrust|language=en|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref> (1990-1992) * [[Frank Lui]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015073049192;view=1up;seq=74|title=Chiefs of State and Cabinet members of foreign governments / National Foreign Assessment Center. Jan-Apr 1994.|website=HathiTrust|language=en|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref> (1993-1996) * Togia Sioneholo (2008-2011) [referred to as the Minister of Justice, Lands and Survey] * Halene Magatogia<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/242556/big-changes-in-niue-cabinet|title=Big changes in Niue Cabinet|date=2014-04-25|work=Radio New Zealand|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en-nz}}</ref> (2011-2014) [referred to as the Minister of Justice, Lands and Survey]

{{distinguish|Banknote}} {{Redirect|Supply bill|bills on government spending|Appropriation bill|the Irish controversy of 1753–1756|Money Bill dispute}} In the [[Westminster system]] (and, colloquially, in the [[United States]]), a '''money bill''' or '''supply bill ''' is a [[bill (proposed law)|bill]] that solely concerns [[taxation]] or [[government spending]] (also known as [[Appropriation (law)|appropriation]] of money), as opposed to changes in public law. == Conventions == It is often a [[constitutional convention (political custom)|constitutional convention]] that the [[upper house]] may not block a money bill. There is often another requirement that non-money bill-type clauses may not be attached to a money bill. The rationale behind this convention is that the upper house, being appointed or indirectly elected, should not have any right to decide on taxation and public expenditure-related policies as may be framed by the directly elected representatives of the lower house. Therefore, money bills are an exception to the general rule that for a bill to be enacted into a law, it has to be approved by both Houses of the Parliament—the lower house and the upper house.Datta, Pratik; Malhotra, Shefali; Tyagi, Shivangi. [http://www.nipfp.org.in/media/medialibrary/2017/03/WP_2017_192.pdf "Judicial Review and Money Bills"]. National Institute of Public Finance and Policy Working Paper No. 192. Retrieved 24 March 2017. [[Loss of supply]] in the [[lower house]] is conventionally considered to be an expression of the house's [[motion of no confidence|loss of confidence]] in the government resulting in the government's fall. == Requirements in Westminster systems == === Australia === A supply bill in the Australian System is required to pass the [[Australian House of Representatives|House of Representatives]], the [[Australian Senate|Senate]] and be signed by the [[Governor-General of Australia|Governor-General]]. The Senate has no power or ability to introduce or modify a supply bill, but has the ability to block or defer the passing of a supply bill. The most famous instance where supply was blocked was during the [[1975 Australian constitutional crisis|1975 constitutional crisis]]. This has resulted in agreements between political parties to prevent the blockage of supply bills through the Senate. === Bangladesh === A money bill is specifically defined by Article 81 of the [[Constitution of Bangladesh]]. The [[President of Bangladesh]] can send back all bills passed by the [[Jatiyo Sangshad|Parliament]] for a review except a money bill. However, a money bill can be introduced to the [[Jatiyo Sangshad|Parliament]] only at the President's recommendation. Additionally, tax can only be levied by the Parliament.{{cite web|title=Constitution of Bangladesh|url=http://www1.umn.edu/humanrts/research/bangladesh-constitution.pdf|accessdate=3 December 2011}} === India === Procedure for a Money Bill: #Money Bills can be introduced only in [[Lok Sabha]] (the directly elected 'people's house' of the Indian Parliament). #Money bills passed by the Lok Sabha are sent to the [[Rajya Sabha]] (the upper house of parliament, elected by the state and territorial legislatures or appointed by the [[President of India|president]]). The Rajya Sabha may not amend money bills but can recommend amendments. To make sure that Rajya Sabha doesn't amend the bill by adding some non-money matters (known as Financial Bill), the [[Speaker of the Lok Sabha]] certifies the bill as a money bill before sending it to the upper house, and the decision of the Speaker is binding on both the Houses.{{cite web|url=http://parliamentofindia.nic.in/ls/rules/rulep10.html |title=Rules of the Lok Sabha |publisher=Parliamentofindia.nic.in |date= |accessdate=2016-02-17}} A money bill must be returned to the Lok Sabha within 14 days, or the bill is deemed to have passed both houses in the form it was originally passed by the Lok Sabha. #When a Money Bill is returned to the Lok Sabha with the recommended amendments of the Rajya Sabha, it is open to the Lok Sabha to accept or reject any or all of the recommendations. #A money bill is deemed to have passed both houses with any recommended amendments the Lok Sabha chooses to accept, and without any that it chooses to decline. # The definition of "Money Bill" is given in Article 110 of [[The Constitution of India]]. A financial bill is not a Money Bill unless it fulfills the requirements of Article 110. #The Speaker of the Lok Sabha certifies if a financial bill is a Money Bill or not.{{cite web|last1=Datta|first1=Pratik|last2=Malhotra|first2=Shefali|last3=Tyagi|first3=Shivangi|title=Judicial Review and Money Bills|url=http://www.nipfp.org.in/media/medialibrary/2017/03/WP_2017_192.pdf|publisher=National Institute of Public Finance and Policy|accessdate=24 March 2017|ref=Judicial Review and Money Bills}} #Policy cut motion - disapproval of the given policy. Symbolically, the members demand that the amount of the demand be reduced to 1 INR. They may also suggest an alternative policy. #Economy cut motion - it is demanded that the amount of the policy be reduced by a specified amount. #Token cut motion - used to show specific grievance against the government. Also states that the amount of the demand be reduced by Rs. 100. #A money bill can only be introduced in parliament with prior permission of the [[President of India]]. #Finance bill is supposed to be enacted within 75 days (including the Parliament voting and the President assenting). #Money bill cannot be returned by the President to the parliament for its reconsideration, as it is presented in the Lok Sabha with his permission. The concept of money bills in India came to the forefront during the enactment of the Aadhar Act, 2016. In spite of resistance by the opposition, the Aadhaar Bill was certified as a ‘money bill’ by the Speaker of the Lower House. The Upper House proposed certain amendments, but ultimately the [[Bharatiya Janata Party|BJP]]-dominated Lower House rejected the amendments suggested by the Upper House and unilaterally enacted the Aadhar Act, 2016. Immediately thereafter, [[Jairam Ramesh]], a senior [[Indian National Congress|Congress]] leader, challenged the speaker’s decision to treat the Aadhar Bill as a ‘money bill’ before the Supreme Court of India. Article 110(3) of the Constitution of India categorically states that 'if any question arises whether a Bill is a Money Bill or not, the decision of the Speaker of the House of the People thereon shall be final'. Therefore, one of the prime constitutional questions before the Supreme Court is whether it can review the speaker’s certificate classifying a bill as a ‘money bill’. In three prior cases, the [[Supreme Court of India]] has refused to review the Speaker's certificate. However, some commentators have argued that the Court's earlier judgements were incorrect and Article 110(3) made the Speaker’s decision "final" for the purpose of the two Houses of the Parliament, not for the Supreme Court of India.{{cite web|last1=Datta|first1=Pratik|last2=Malhotra|first2=Shefali|last3=Tyagi|first3=Shivangi|title=Judicial Review and Money Bills|url=http://www.nipfp.org.in/media/medialibrary/2017/03/WP_2017_192.pdf|publisher=National Institute of Public Finance and Policy|accessdate=24 March 2017|ref=Judicial Review and Money Bills}} This argument is further supported by the fact that in [https://indiankanoon.org/doc/1686885/ Kihoto Hollohan vs Zachillhu (AIR 1993 SC 412)], the "final" decision of the speaker regarding disqualification of members of the House under the Tenth Schedule of the Indian Constitution was held to be a judicial decision subject to judicial review. This suggests that the "final" status given by the Indian constitution does not automatically immune the Indian speaker's decision or certificate from judicial review.{{cite web|last1=Datta|first1=Pratik|last2=Malhotra|first2=Shefali|last3=Tyagi|first3=Shivangi|title=Judicial Review and Money Bills|url=http://www.nipfp.org.in/media/medialibrary/2017/03/WP_2017_192.pdf|publisher=National Institute of Public Finance and Policy|accessdate=24 March 2017|ref=Judicial Review and Money Bills}} In view of this crucial constitutional question, it has been suggested that the Supreme Court in ''Jairam Ramesh v. Union of India'' should create a constitution bench of at least nine judges to settle the law on this issue.{{cite web|last1=Arun|first1=T.K.|title=The Money Bill conundrum: Constitution bench should decide|url=http://blogs.economictimes.indiatimes.com/cursor/the-money-bill-conundrum-constitution-bench-should-decide/|publisher=The Economic Times|accessdate=6 April 2017|ref=The Money Bill conundrum}}The five judge bench in the ratio 4-1 decided that the Aadhar Bill was a Money Bill === Republic of Ireland === In the [[Republic of Ireland]], the [[Seanad Éireann|Senate]] may not delay a money bill ({{Lang-ga|bille airgid}})https://www.oireachtas.ie/viewdoc.asp?fn=/documents/a-misc/legi.htm more than 21 days. The [[President of Ireland]] may not refuse to sign a money bill and may not refer such a bill to the [[Supreme Court (Ireland)|Supreme Court]] to test its [[constitutionality]]. Procedures exist for resolution of disputes as to whether a Bill is a money bill. Since the 1922 constitution (as amended by the [[Constitution (Amendment No. 12) Act 1930]]) and under the 1937 constitution, such disputes can be resolved by a committee on privileges. === United Kingdom === In the [[United Kingdom]], section 1(1) of the [[Parliament Act 1911]] provides that the [[House of Lords]] may not delay a money bill more than a month. It is at the discretion of the [[Speaker of the House of Commons (United Kingdom)|Speaker of the House of Commons]] to certify which bills are money bills, and his decision is final and is not subject to challenge. Section 1(2) of the Act states:
A Money Bill means a [[Public Bill]] which in the opinion of the Speaker of the House of Commons contains only provisions dealing with all or any of the following subjects, namely, the imposition, repeal, remission, alteration, or regulation of taxation; the imposition for the payment of debt or other financial purposes of charges on the [[Consolidated Fund]], the [[National Loans Fund]] or on money provided by Parliament, or the variation or repeal of any such charges; supply; the appropriation, receipt, custody, issue or audit of accounts of public money; the raising or guarantee of any loan or the repayment thereof; or subordinate matters incidental to those subjects or any of them. In this subsection the expressions "taxation," "public money," and "loan" respectively do not include any taxation, money, or loan raised by local authorities or bodies for local purposes.{{cite web|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Geo5/1-2/13/section/1 |title=Parliament Act 1911 |publisher=Legislation.gov.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-02-17}}
The Parliament Act 1911 was the product of the political crisis of 1909. The People's Budget of 1909 proposed by the House of Commons was rejected by the House of Lords. A government whose budget (that is the Finance Bill) is rejected can only resign or dissolve Parliament, because without money it is impossible to govern. The rejection of the Finance Bill in 1909 by the Lords prompted the then British government to initiate steps to curtail the powers of the House of Lords in this regard. This is evident from the Preamble of the 1911 Act which states: "An Act to make provision with respect to the powers of the House of Lords in relation to those of the House of Commons ...".Datta, Pratik; Malhotra, Shefali; Tyagi, Shivangi. [http://www.nipfp.org.in/media/medialibrary/2017/03/WP_2017_192.pdf "Judicial Review and Money Bills"]. National Institute of Public Finance and Policy Working Paper No. 192. Retrieved 24 March 2017. The reference to the National Loans Fund was inserted on 1 April 1968The National Loans Act 1968, [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1968/13/section/24 section 24(3)] by [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1968/13/section/1 section 1(5)] of the [[National Loans Act 1968]]. For this purpose, the expression "Public Bill" does not include any Bill for confirming a [[Provisional Order]]. Bradley and Ewing said that the statutory definition of Money Bill is "strictly interpreted".A W Bradley and K D Ewing, Constitutional and Administrative Law, Twelfth Edition, Longman, 1997, p. 213 Most annual [[Finance Act|Finance Bills]] have not been certified to be Money Bills.A W Bradley and K D Ewing, Constitutional and Administrative Law, Twelfth Edition, Longman, 1997, pp. 213 and 214Erskine May, Parliamentary Practice, 21st Edition, 1989, pp. 751–753 (editor C Gorden)Jennings, I. Parliament, Second Edition, 1957 == Requirements in non-Westminster systems == === United States === While the [[United States of America]] is not a parliamentary democracy, the [[Origination Clause]] of the U.S. Constitution requires that all bills raising revenue originate in the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]], consistent with British constitutional practice; by convention, [[appropriation bill]]s (bills that ''spend'' money) also originate in the House. Unlike in most Westminster systems, there are no limits on the [[United States Senate|Senate's]] ability to amend revenue bills or any requirement for the Senate to approve such bills within a certain timeframe. Both appropriations and revenue bills are often referred to as money bills to contrast them with [[authorization bill]]s. The U.S. Supreme Court in [[United States v. Munoz-Flores|United States v. Munoz-Flores (1990)]] held that: "A law passed in violation of the Origination Clause would thus be no more immune from judicial scrutiny because it was passed by both Houses and signed by the President than would be a law passed in violation of the First Amendment".Datta, Pratik; Malhotra, Shefali; Tyagi, Shivangi. "Judicial Review and Money Bills"[http://www.nipfp.org.in/media/medialibrary/2017/03/WP_2017_192.pdf]. National Institute of Public Finance and Policy Working Paper No. 192. Retrieved 24 March 2017. == See also == * [[Appropriation bill]] * [[Power of the purse]] == References == {{DEFAULTSORT:Money Bill}} [[Category:Statutory law]] [[Category:Westminster system]] [[Category:Government finances]]

'''Opinion evidence''' refers to evidence of what the witness thinks, believes, or infers in regard to facts, as distinguished from personal knowledge of the facts themselves.<ref name="freedict">{{Cite web|url=http://legal-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/Opinion+Evidence|title=Opinion Evidence|work=The Free Dictionary|accessdate=October 11, 2010}}</ref> In [[common law jurisdiction]]s the general rule is that a witness is supposed to testify as to what was observed and not to give an opinion on what was observed. However, there are two exceptions to this rule: [[expert evidence]] and non-expert opinion given by laymen which people in their daily lives reach without conscious [[ratiocination]].
== General rule == In general, witnesses should testify only as to the facts observed and should not give opinion.<ref>{{cite book |title=Cross & Tapper on Evidence (10th edn) |last=Tapper |first=Colin |year=2004 |publisher=Lexis Nexis |location=UK |isbn=978-0-406-95004-8 |page=556}}</ref>
The main rationale for such a rule is that the admission of opinion evidence would not assist, or might even mislead, the court and in particular the jury. This is because opinion evidence is usually irrelevant. Moreover, admission of such evidence would usurp the functions of the jury, which alone should be the tribunal of fact and draw its own inferences.<ref>{{cite book |title=Cross & Tapper on Evidence (10th edn) |last=Tapper |first=Colin |year=2004 |publisher=Lexis Nexis |location=UK |isbn=978-0-406-95004-8 |page=558}}</ref>
== Expert evidence == {{Main|Expert evidence}} An expert witness is a [[witness]], who by virtue of [[education]], [[training]], [[skill]], or [[experience]], is believed to have [[expert]]ise and specialised [[knowledge]] in a particular subject beyond that of the average person, sufficient that others may officially and legally rely upon the witness's specialized ([[Scientific evidence (law)|scientific]], technical or other) opinion about an [[evidence]] or [[fact]] issue within the scope of his expertise, referred to as the expert opinion, as an assistance to the [[fact-finder]].<ref>Federal Rule of Evidence 702 (As amended April 17, 2000, effective December 1, 2000)</ref> Expert witnesses may also deliver expert evidence about facts from the domain of their expertise.<ref>''[[Black's Law Dictionary]]'', articles "Evidence", "Expert", "Witness"</ref> The facts upon which an expert opinion is based must be proved by admissible evidence.<ref>R v Turner [1975] QB 834</ref> The duty of experts is to furnish the judge with the necessary scientific criteria for testing the accuracy of their conclusions, so that the judge or jury can form their own independent judgment by the application of these criteria to the facts proved.<ref>Davie v Edinburgh Magistrates</ref>
== Non-expert opinion == Non-expert opinion refers to the opinion given in restricted circumstances by laymen or persons who do not possess any expertise. These circumstances mainly concern matters of everyday life where a person may be expected to give opinions and which opinions may be safely acted upon by others.
Such circumstances cannot be definitively laid out in a closed list of cases. However, cases in which non-expert opinion has been admitted include: * Apparent age of a person<ref>R v Cox [1898] 1 QB 179</ref> * Apparent age of objects<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.inbrief.co.uk/expert-evidence.htm|title=Expert evidence|work=In Brief|accessdate=October 11, 2010}}</ref> * Speed<ref>R v Cheung Shing-Wai [1993] 1 HKCLR 311</ref> * Weather * Drunkenness <ref>R v Davies [1962] 3 All ER 97</ref> * Identification of handwriting * [[Eyewitness identification]] * Identification of physical objects * The general body condition or emotional state of a person<ref>R v Davies [1962] 1 WLR 1111</ref> * The general condition of objects * The approximate value of objects<ref>R v Beckett (1913) 8 Cr App R 204</ref> * Approximate distance<ref>R v Ireland (No. 2) [1971] SASR 6</ref> * Time * Ability to speak and understand a language<ref>R v Decha-Iamsakun [1993] 1 NZLR 141</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Distinguish|Regulation D (SEC)}} {{Refimprove|date=January 2011}} '''Reserve Requirements for Depository Institutions''' ({{USCFR|12|204}}, '''Regulation D''') is a [[Federal Reserve Board of Governors|Federal Reserve]] regulation which sets out [[Reserve requirement|reserve requirements]] for [[Banking in the United States|banks in the United States]]. It is more familiar to the public as the regulation that limits monthly withdrawals from savings accounts.
==Reserve requirement== The regulation requires depository institutions to keep cash reserves in order to meet immediate withdrawals against their transaction accounts. The minimum reserve requirement is 3% of the total amount over $16 million, and an additional 7% of the amount over $122.3 million. The institution may satisfy the requirement with [[bank vault|vault]] cash and with deposits at a [[Federal Reserve Bank]], or a bank that acts as a Federal Reserve [[correspondent account|correspondent]]. [[Bankers' bank]]s and [[corporate credit union]]s, which act only as correspondents for other institutions, are not subject to the reserve requirements. The [[Federal Reserve Board of Governors]] may require additional reserves after consulting Congress or [[deposit insurance]] authorities.<ref>{{USCFR|12|204}}</ref>
==Six-transaction limit== In consumer banking, "Regulation D" often refers to §204.2(d)(2) of the regulation, which limits withdrawals or outgoing transfers from a [[Savings account|savings]] or [[Money market account|money market]] account. No more than six such transactions per [[bank statement|statement]] period may be made from an account by various "convenient" methods, which include [[cheque|checks]], [[debit card]] payments, and automatic transactions such as [[automated clearing house]] transfers or [[electronic bill payment]]. Institutions must warn any customer that exceeds the limit and must freeze, close or reclassify accounts that do so repeatedly. The regulation does not limit transactions made in person, at an [[automated teller machine|ATM]], by mail, or by telephone request for a mailed check. Even in these cases, the institution may require seven-day advance written notice before releasing funds. This right is not normally exercised, but it must be part of the account agreement.<ref>''Savings Deposits'', in [http://www.federalreserve.gov/boarddocs/supmanual/cch/int_depos.pdf Regulation D - Reserve requirements], Federal Reserve,</ref>
Each institution sets its own specific policies for responding to violations of the limit. [[Discover Financial|Discover Bank]], for example, will close a savings account if Regulation D is exceeded 3 or more times in a 12-month period. [[Wells Fargo]] charges a $15 "Excess Activity Fee" for each item cleared after the regulation has been exceeded, and converts the account to a checking account if the activity persists.<ref>Wells Fargo, "[https://www.wellsfargo.com/help/checking-savings/glossary/ Savings & Checking Account Definitions: Excess Activity]"</ref>
The regulation was amended in 2009 to allow greater freedom for the depositor: beforehand, the limit was six withdrawals per month if the funds remained within the same institution (e.g., transfer to checking), but was only three drafts where the funds left the institution (e.g., check, [[ACH Network]], or card based purchase).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edocket.access.gpo.gov/2009/E9-12431.htm|title=Federal Register, Volume 74 Issue 102 (Friday, May 29, 2009)|website=edocket.access.gpo.gov|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Savings account]] * [[Money market account]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr&sid=635f26c4af3e2fe4327fd25ef4cb5638&tpl=/ecfrbrowse/Title12/12cfr204_main_02.tpl FRB 12 CFR 204 ("Regulation D")] * [http://www.ecfr.gov/cgi-bin/text-idx?c=ecfr&sid=635f26c4af3e2fe4327fd25ef4cb5638&tpl=/ecfrbrowse/Title12/12cfr204_main_02.tpl Regulation D of the Federal Reserve] * [https://www.fdic.gov/regulations/laws/rules/7500-500.html FDIC PART 204—RESERVE REQUIREMENTS OF DEPOSITORY INSTITUTIONS (REGULATION D)]

{{Infobox company | name = Rocky Rococo Pizza and Pasta | logo = Rocky Rococo Logo.png | type = Private | foundation = [[Madison, Wisconsin]], [[United States|U.S.]] (1974) | location_city = | location_country = United States | location = [[Oconomowoc, Wisconsin]] | locations = 40 | key_people = Thomas R. (Tom) Hester, CEO and Owner
Trey Hester, President and CEO
Wayne Mosley, Founder/Franchisee
Roger Brown, Founder/Franchisee
| area_served = | industry = Restaurant, Delivery | products = Pizza, Pasta, Salad | services = | revenue = US$ 41,000,000 | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = Rocky Rococo Corporation | divisions = | subsid = | caption = | homepage = [http://rockyrococo.com rockyrococo.com] | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''Rocky Rococo Pizza and Pasta''' is a chain of North American restaurants that specializes in pan-style pizza sold [[Pizza by the slice|by the slice]]. It was founded in [[Madison, Wisconsin]] in 1974 by a pair of college students who took the name from a character invented in 1969 by [[the Firesign Theatre]]. The Firesign Theatre claimed ownership of the name and threatened legal action in 1985, but according to legal precedent set by a similar case in Austin, Texas, they had weakened their case for [[copyright infringement]] in a 1975 visit to the first Rocky Rococo store, when they gave the owners autographed pictures, which implied their approval of the name use. The chain grew as large as 120 stores in 1986, and the owners sold the franchise rights to another partner and group of investors in 1988. Today there are still 40 locations in the Midwest. == History == Wayne Mosley and Roger Brown opened their first store in [[Madison, Wisconsin]], in 1974. The name "Rocky [[Rococo]]" was invented in 1969 by [[the Firesign Theatre]] for a villain in the "Further Adventures of [[Nick Danger]]" sketch on their second [[comedy album]], ''[[How Can You Be in Two Places at Once When You're Not Anywhere at All]]''. The character was based on [[Dashiell Hammett]]'s Joel Cairo as portrayed by [[Peter Lorre]] in the 1941 film ''[[The Maltese Falcon (1941 film)|The Maltese Falcon]]''. The name is a parody of a character invented by [[the Beatles]] for their song ''[[Rocky Raccoon]]''. The Firesign character is described as a [[dwarfism|dwarf]] and depicted as bald and wearing a [[fez]]. The company's web site does not mention either the Firesign Theatre or the Beatles character as inspiration for the name. To design their restaurant's logo, Mosley and Brown hired a Madison artist to sketch a character based on the [[Spy vs. Spy|White Spy]] character from [[Mad Magazine]], and hired comic actor Jim Pederson to portray their "Rocky Rococo" mascot as a moustachioed Italian wearing a white suit, wide-brimmed hat, and sunglasses. Pederson died at age 68 on February 4, 2016.{{cite news|last1=Shultz|first1=Rob|title=Jim Pederson, the face and personality of Rocky Rococo Pizza for decades, dies|url=http://host.madison.com/wsj/news/local/jim-pederson-the-face-and-personality-of-rocky-rococo-pizza/article_cda897af-2f3c-51d2-935d-85371fab969a.html|accessdate=November 3, 2017|work=Wisconsin State Journal|agency=Madison.com|date=February 9, 2016}} ==Copyright infringement== The Firesign Theatre visited the first Rocky Rococo Pizza when on tour in Madison in 1975, and reacted with good humor, joking around with the owners and giving them pictures that said, "To Rocky, from Rocky" which were hung on the wall. But in 1985, when the chain had grown to 62 restaurants, the Firesign Theatre sent the owners a letter claiming ownership of the name. Their lawyers found a similar case where an Austin, Texas pizzeria named Conan's ran afoul of the copyright owners, producers of the 1982 film ''[[Conan the Barbarian (1982 film)|Conan the Barbarian]]''. Since the creator of the [[Conan the Barbarian (comics)|''Conan the Barbarian'' comic]] had similarly endorsed the restaurant by drawing Conan on its walls, the suit lost in the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit]]. So the Firesigns settled out of court.{{cite news |last=Breuer |first=Tom |date=March 2014 |title=Rocky Rococo celebrates 40-year slice of success |url=http://www.ibmadison.com/In-Business-Madison/March-2014/Rocky-Rococo-celebrates-40-year-slice-of-success/index.php?cparticle=2&siarticle=1#artanc |work=In Business Madison |location=Madison, Wisconsin |access-date=February 28, 2018 }} By 1986, the chain had grown to 120 stores, according to the company. Mosley and Brown sold the franchise rights to Tom Hester and a group of investors in 1988. Mosley died at his home in Madison on November 28, 2017, aged 70.{{cite news|author= |title=Rocky Rococo pizza co-founder dies at 70|url=http://www.channel3000.com/news/rocky-rococo-pizza-co-founder-dies-at-70/664156326|work=WISC-TV Channel3000.com |location=Madison, Wisconsin |date=November 29, 2017 |accessdate=February 28, 2018}} == Locations == [[File:Rocky Rococo's Party Pizzeria East - panoramio.jpg|thumb|Location in [[Madison, Wisconsin]]]] {{Asof|2014}}, there were 40 Rocky Rococo locations, mostly in [[Wisconsin]], and one each in [[Minnesota]] and [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]].[http://order.rockyrococo.com/Locations.aspx?all=t Rocky Rococo Locations] The chain generates about $40 million in annual sales.[http://milwaukee.bizjournals.com/milwaukee/stories/2007/12/03/story8.html The Business Journal of Milwaukee, 11-30-2007, retrieved 10-08-2009] The chain previously had locations in Florida, [[Colorado]], [[Nebraska]], [[Missouri]], [[Michigan]], [[Iowa]], [[Indiana]], [[Illinois]], [[Kentucky]] and [[Ohio]]. ==See also== * [[List of pizza chains of the United States]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.rockyrococo.com}} {{Pizza chains|state=Wisconsin}} {{Fast-food chains of the United States}} [[Category:Pizza chains of the United States]] [[Category:Copyright infringement]] [[Category:Companies based in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Economy of Madison, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Regional restaurant chains in the United States]]

{{Infobox school district |logo = [[Image:SJUSD Logo FullColor Name.png|250px|Image: 250 pixels]] |name = San José Unified School District |type = Public School District |budget = |established = |region = [[Santa Clara County]] |grades = K-12 |superintendent = Nancy Albarrán |teachers = |staff = |students = 32,004<ref>https://dq.cde.ca.gov/dataquest/DQ/EnrTimeRpt.aspx?Level=District&cYear=2016-17&cname=San%20Jose%20Unified&cCode=4369666</ref> |conference = |schools= 41 |location = [[San Jose, California]] |country = [[United States]] |website = {{URL|http://web.sjusd.org/}} }}
'''San José Unified School District''' is a TK-12 [[school district]] in [[Santa Clara County, California]] and covers a large portion of the city of [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], [[California]]. The district has more than 3,000 full-time employees serving approximately 30,000 students in 41 schools from downtown San José in the north to the Almaden Valley in the south.
==Mission and Vision== San José Unified's vision is "preparing today’s students to be the thinkers, leaders, and creators of tomorrow." The district's mission is to "elevate opportunities for all".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.sjusd.org/who-we-are/our-story/}}</ref>
==History== San Jose City School District was founded in 1853 and renamed San Jose Unified School District in 1936. In the late 1990s, a fire sprinkler broke in the basement of the district office, destroying many of the district's historic documents. District staff and local historians have been working ever since to rebuild the district archive.
Over 164 years, San José Unified has supported 17 elementary schools, of which 38 remain active as of the 2017-2018 school year. Additionally, the district supports six comprehensive middle schools, six comprehensive high schools, a continuation high school, and an alternative education school.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.sjusd.org/our-schools/schools/}}</ref>
A state law passed in the 1950s required certain elementary districts to either build their own high school or be annexed by a district that already had a high school. Thus, in 1956, the voters in Almaden Union School District elected to merge with San José Unified.<ref>{{cite news|agency=San Jose Mercury News|date=January 18, 1956}}</ref>
In 1983 Federal Bankruptcy Judge [[Seymour Abrahams]] declared the school board bankrupt under Chapter 9. The judge rolled back employee wages.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/30/us/san-jose-schools-can-cut-pay-us-bankruptcy-court-rules.html</ref>
